org.jetel.data

Class DataRecordImpl

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jetel.data.DataRecord
      • org.jetel.data.DataRecordImpl
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Comparable<java.lang.Object>, java.lang.Iterable<DataField>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    DataRecordWithInvalidState, NullRecord, Token

    public class DataRecordImpl
extends DataRecord
    A class that represents one data record with structure based on provided metadata object.
    Fields of this data record are created only once and updated when it is needed.
    When we need to send record through the EDGE (or other communication channel), we just serialize it to stream of bytes (it isn't standard Java serializing, but Clover's own).
    Since:
    March 26, 2002
    See Also:
    DataRecordMetadata, Serialized Form

      • copyFrom

        public void copyFrom(DataRecord fromRecord)
        Set fields by copying the fields from the record passed as argument. Does not assume that both records have the right same structure - i.e. metadata.
        Specified by:
        copyFrom in class DataRecord
        Parameters:
        fromRecord - DataRecord from which to get fields' values

      • copyFieldsByPosition

        public void copyFieldsByPosition(DataRecord sourceRecord)
        Set fields by copying the fields from the record passed as argument. Can handle situation when records are not exactly the same. For incompatible fields default value is setted. This operation is not intended for time critical purposes - in this case consider to use copyFrom() method instead.
        Specified by:
        copyFieldsByPosition in class DataRecord
        Parameters:
        sourceRecord - Record from which fields are copied
        Since:

      • copyFieldsByName

        public boolean[] copyFieldsByName(DataRecord sourceRecord)
        Set fields by copying name-matching fields' values from the record passed as argument.
        If two fields match by name but not by type, target field is set to default value. For incompatible fields default value is set. This operation is not intended for time critical purposes - in this case consider to use copyFrom() method instead.
        Specified by:
        copyFieldsByName in class DataRecord
        Parameters:
        sourceRecord - from which copy data
        Returns:
        boolean array with true values on positions, where values were copied from source record

      • delField

        public void delField(int _fieldNum)
        Deletes/removes specified field. The field's internal reference is set to NULL, so it can be garbage collected.
        Warning:We recommend not using this method !
        By calling this method, the number of fields is decreased by one, the internal array containing fields is copied into a new one.
        Be careful when calling this method as the modified record won't follow the original metadata prescription. New metadata object will be created and assigned to this record, but it will share fields' metadata with the original metadata object.
        Specified by:
        delField in class DataRecord
        Parameters:
        _fieldNum - Description of Parameter
        Since:

      • deserializeUnitary

        public void deserializeUnitary(CloverBuffer buffer)
        Unitary deserialization should be compatible with unitary serialization. Moreover this type of unitary serialization and deserialization should be compatible with all descendants of DataRecord - for now it is only Token and DataRecord. So for example serialized DataRecord can be deserialized into Token and vice versa.
        Specified by:
        deserializeUnitary in class DataRecord

      • equals

        public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
        Test two DataRecords for equality. Records must have the same metadata (be created using the same metadata object) and their field values must be equal.
        Specified by:
        equals in class DataRecord
        Parameters:
        obj - DataRecord to compare with
        Returns:
        True if they equals, false otherwise
        Since:
        April 23, 2002

      • compareTo

        public int compareTo(java.lang.Object obj)
        Compares two DataRecords. Records must have the same metadata (be created using the same metadata object). Their field values are compare one by one, the first non-equal pair of fields denotes the overall comparison result.
        Specified by:
        compareTo in interface java.lang.Comparable<java.lang.Object>
        Specified by:
        compareTo in class DataRecord
        See Also:
        Comparable.compareTo(java.lang.Object)

      • setMetadata

        public void setMetadata(DataRecordMetadata metadata)
        Assigns new metadata to this DataRecord. If the new metadata is not equal to the current metadata, the record's content is recreated from scratch. After calling this method, record is uninitialized and init() method should be called prior any attempt to manipulate this record's content.
        Specified by:
        setMetadata in class DataRecord
        Parameters:
        metadata - The new Metadata value
        Since:
        April 5, 2002

      • reset

        public void reset()
        An operation which sets/resets all fields to their initial value (just after they were created by JVM) - it varies depending on type of field.
        Nullable fields are set to NULL, non-nullable are zeroed, if they have default value defined, then default value is assigned.
        Specified by:
        reset in class DataRecord

      • reset

        public void reset(int _fieldNum)
        An operation that resets value of specified field - by calling its reset() method.
        Specified by:
        reset in class DataRecord
        Parameters:
        _fieldNum - Ordinal number of the field which should be set to default

      • getSizeSerializedUnitary

        public int getSizeSerializedUnitary()
        Size of unitary serialization form of this data record. Unitary deserialization should be compatible with unitary serialization. Moreover this type of unitary serialization and deserialization should be compatible with all descendants of DataRecord - for now it is only Token and DataRecord. So for example serialized DataRecord can be deserialized into Token and vice versa.
        Specified by:
        getSizeSerializedUnitary in class DataRecord
